thread.title: WATCH: Trey Gowdy Won’t Put Up with Dems’ Games, Pulls No Punches with Comey
thread.title_full: WATCH: Trey Gowdy Won’t Put Up with Dems’ Games, Pulls No Punches with Comey

author: Ben Marquis
title: WATCH: Trey Gowdy Won’t Put Up with Dems’ Games, Pulls No Punches with Comey
text:
John Elway Gives Neil Gorsuch a Glowing Public Endorsement 
Real Clear Politics reported that Gowdy used the bulk of his time to grill Comey on who has the authority to “unmask” a U.S. citizen caught up in foreign surveillance, and though Comey remained infuriatingly vague at times, Gowdy pressed politely but relentlessly. 
Comey said he was unable off the top of his head to give a specific number regarding how many people in the FBI would have authority to “unmask” a U.S. citizen — explaining that he could obtain such a number — instead speaking about the “culture” of the agency and how it takes unmasking and leaking very seriously, though he also refused to confirm or deny whether recent leaks were being duly investigated. 
Gowdy found Comey to be slightly more forthcoming once his questions were framed in a theoretical fashion, and eventually was able to obtain confirmation that several top members of the former Obama administration would have been capable of unmasking U.S. citizens in the investigation, resulting in the unlawful release of an individual’s name. Advertisement - story continues below 
Those individuals would include former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former CIA Director John Brennan, former National Security Adviser Susan Rice, former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, former acting AG Sally Yates, and possibly even former White House adviser Ben Rhodes. 
You can watch part of the back-and-forth right here: 
According to a transcript prepared by CNBC , Gowdy continued to press Comey regarding the leaks of sensitive information about the investigation, but Comey remained cagey in refusing to either confirm or deny any of the specifics of Gowdy’s probes. Advertisement - story continues below
